text:
Once I went to a restaurant and I wanted to
have something to drink and eat. So this waitress

came along and she asked me a question
“Hi! Can I get-ya some soda to have?”

I said
“Soda? No! I just wanna have a glass of

coke, please?”
That’s the first time I heard a sound in

my mind (drum beat sound). I knew something
was wrong. The waitress gave me a very am-

gave me a very amused look and she said
“Okay? A glass of coke. Do you wanna a high

tea?”
High tea? No! I just want some normal sandwich

to have. I don’t want tea I just want coke
and a sandwich to eat, mam, please.

By then the waiters looked very upset and
in my mind I had this music…(drum beats).

I knew, probably, I am not aware of the vocabulary
she is using. Right? And I am sure, a lot

of you come across this situation where you
are too embarrassed to ask or you say something

which you are not sure of, especially in a
restaurant, it may… it gives you er… how

to say, it puts you in a bad light. Right?
I am sure you had.
My name is Emmelda, and

today I will help you escape all of those
embarrassing moments by learning or introducing

you some very unusual snack time vocabulary.
Now, why are they unusual? Because certain

vocabularies are, actually, not practised
quiet popularly, they may be practised only

in certain countries but now they are getting
popular slowly and steadily. So If you are

travelling to any country where such vocabulary
is used, you will not feel very embarrassed,

or at least, as embarrassed as I felt at that
time. SO let’s get started. The first one

I have is Nibble on! What is nibble on? Have
you ever seen a cow munching? (cow munching

sound). Yes, that’s actually what nibble
on means. Nibble on means to munch. Ok er

What will you munch? You’ll munch a canopy,
a san.. no I’ll not say sandwich, but those

small small tarts, canopy or anything, which
is small and you just want to, you know, pass

your time. You don’t… You aren’t really
hungry. Just want to eat something. You just

want your jaws moving. SO you munch like a
cow (cow munching sound) Yes! You nibble on

a canopy. The next as I said is High tea.
The next one I have is high tea. When she

said High tea. I was wondering “what kind
of tea is she offering? I asked for a soda.

No! High tea is actually a word from Ireland.
It is used as early dinner from 7-9. And it’s

a small and early dinner. That was the original
word. That was the original meaning. But now

High tea means refreshment. It’s refreshment.
So anytime you are talking about snacks or

something small that you want to munch, they
sometimes use the word “High-tea”. In

fact, if you happen to go to Singapore you
will have restaurants claiming they have High-tea

menu for you. Okay, so next time, if you come
across the word High-tea, you know mean…

they just mean some refreshment usually for
the dinner time. Okay? The next I have for

you is Savoury. Now savoury is common or for
that matter another term for snack. However,

savoury initially meant both, something that
is not sweet as well as sweet like cakes,

pastries or sandwiches. But now-a-days, savoury
is meant or probably used only for things

that are not sweet. So, may be your sandwiches
or your… how to say… or puffs. the puffs?

The puffed sandwich. Yes! That they call as
savoury. Now a days no body uses savoury for

something sweet. They use it for something
which is salty, which you can have it with

tea or coffee. Alright? So now that you have
something salty, obviously you wanna have

something sweet, right? Good! For those, I
have confections. Confections are baked products

that are very rich in…guess the word…sugar
and carbohydrate. So those who are watching

their waist line, you may not want to have
a confection. Oh! Who makes those confections?

Of course, the bakers. So, confection is rich
in sugar and carbohydrates. Obviously what

kind of confections are we talking about.
I am gonna talking about tarts. Now, tarts

are those small pieces. They like they are
this small. They are very colourful . They

have a very strong firm base…yeah! But it’s
damn tiny so it’s … the base is very firm,

however, the top portion is very and open.
We may have fruit tarts. Some tarts are actually

big, but usually tarts come only in this size.
Yea! Chinses like tarts. During their Chinese

festivals, you will see people giving them
egg tarts or lemon tarts. Right. That’s

tarts. Not really common in how shall I say
in Europe but very common in America. my favourite…

cakes. Have you ever heard of chocolate cakes
or pineapple cake? Yes, of course! You know..

they are quiet smooth and nice. So cake is
something very common. However, sometimes,

even a sandwich is called a cake. Very rare.
But sometime, people call puffed sandwich

also a cake. So, you may want to be aware
what or what actually the cake mean. You have

cheese cake. Oh! I love cheese cakes. If you
go to America, please go to CheeseCake Factory.

That’s one of my favourite places. Then
we have pastries. Pastries and cakes are pretty

much similar. Again, pastries I call them
a short form of cakes. But, pastries can be…puffs

are called pastries as well. You know. They
can be savoury as well. So, anytime you order

cakes or pastries and if you are not sure,
especially when you are in a foreign country,

you may want to ask for a sweet cake and sweet
pastry and not a savoury one. My favourite…one

more… is macaroons. Macaroons are like those
tiny buttons. Okay? They are really small,

very colourful. The outer crust is like a
biscuit but inside is very soft. And they

actually look something like this. Okay? It
looks like a burger though. So, You see that

back portion, that thick black line I am creating,
that will be a softy. You will be able to

see the filling but the top and bottom will
be very hard as a very soft biscuit. Yeah!

They are not really hard; they are very soft
biscuit. Goes very well with coffee and tea.

Now that I have done the cakes and pastries
I have one word which a lot of people get

confused ‘Water!’ What’s water…I mean
how difficult can it be? But trust me, it’s

difficult. In a restaurant I asked for water.
The first thing the waiters asked me was “still

or gas?” and trust me, this is what my reaction
was. “

No! No! I just want tap water.
Excuse me!

Oh, I just want simple water.”
-What? Mam, do you want something with bubbles

inside or do you just want a plain glass of
water.

I said “Oh, yeah! A plain glass of water,
which is a still water. So, next… I am sorry…

So next time you are see a glass of water
with bubbles in it you may want to say glass

of water with gas or can I have a glass of
water with gas, please? Soda is considered

not the coke soda but the actual soda is considered
a gas water or er… aeriated water, if I

may call that. So, water is not as simple
as you thought. Moving on to next one I have

coffee. Oh I know, everybody loves coffee.
What is so special about coffee? Coffee has

many versions, we have cappuccino, we have
latte, we have mocha. But today I will be

teaching you two very important types of coffees.
What are they? Café Royal and Macchiato.

Café Royale is a teaspoon of brandy with
a cup of coffee. Remember, it’s a teaspoon

of brandy to a coffee and not a teaspoon of
coffee to a brandy. Okay? So brandy with coffee

makes café royal. What is macchiato? Have
you ever heard the word espresso? Have you

heard the word espresso? Yes, you have! But
if you have espresso with a skim milk or milk

with low fat, you call it macchiato! Yes it’s
Macchiato. I think the right pronunciation

is not ‘-toe’ but ‘-tho’. Macchiato
hmhmm espresso with low fat milk. Alright!

For those coffee lovers, I gave you two good
options but I have people who love tea. So

what kind of tea do you have. You have English,
herbal and decaffeinated. A lot of people

don’t know about English it’s a regular
tea black. Some people call English Tea as…where

shall I write it. I’ll write it here no
its liquor tea and I am yeah! Some people

call it liquor tea. Why? Because, it looks
like a brandy or alcohol. So some people call

English tea as liquor tea. Otherwise, people
call liquor tea white, which means English

tea with milk. Now that we have talked about
liquor tea, you may want to talk about herbal

tea. Where do you classify your green tea
or your peppermint tea? You classify them

under herbal tea. I… usually…this is what
the restaurants will write, if they want to

write it on paper “GT” OR “PPT”. Yes
trust me. It’s not a PowerPoint; PPT is

considered as peppermint tea. So next time,
you wanna talk about peppermint tea, you will

see people just writing PPT. Okay? Green tea
or Peppermint tea. One thing to notice, green

tea and peppermint tea will usually have of
lot of caffeine in them. They keep you awake

and some people do not like so much caffeine
to their blood level. So what they do is,

they request for a decaffeinated tea. Decaffeinated
tea means simple words No… So next time

if you are going for a ‘fine dine’ restaurant,
you may want to say “May I have a glass

of decaffeinated tea please? Ah! SO classy,
right? So these are few unusual snack time

vocabulary I had a tough time learning because
I never use to have coffee... I still don’t

have coffee, tea or water with gas or soda.
I keep it very simple, I just go have a glass

of juice or a glass of milk. I know I am a
good girl. Yes! So next time if you go to

a restaurant and you are not sure what the
word would mean, you may want to ask the waitress

or you can immediately go on to YouTube or,
for that matter, check out my lesson and look

out for these phrases. You may find a word
or two. I will be back with new lesson, I

really hope you enjoyed this one though. I
will be back with new lesson. Until then stay

healthy, have fun and watch on your confections.
See you! Babye…
